description: Attested since the 14th century, originally meant a “law or regulation that determines the amount to be payed”, from Middle English syse, sise (“regulation, control, limit”), from Old French cise, sise, aphetism of assise (“assize”), from the verb asseoir (“to sit down”), from Latin assidēre, composed of ad- (“to, towards, at”) +‎ sedeō (“sit; settle down”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *sed-. Displaced native Old English miċelnes (literally “bigness”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete outside dialects) An assize. [from 14th c.]
examples: I know you would have women above the law, but it is all a lye; I heard his lordship say at size, that no one is above the law.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A regulation determining the amount of money paid in fees, taxes etc. [14th–18th c.]
(obsolete) A fixed standard for the magnitude, quality, quantity etc. of goods, especially food and drink. [15th–17th c.]
The dimensions or magnitude of a thing; how big something is. [from 15th c.]
examples: The size of the building seemed to have increased since I was last there.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A regulation, piece of ordinance. [15th c.]
A specific set of dimensions for a manufactured article, especially clothing. [from 16th c.]
examples: I don't think we have the red one in your size.

entries.meaning: (graph theory) A number of edges in a graph. [from 20th c.]
(figurative, dated) Degree of rank, ability, character, etc.
examples: the middle or lower size of people

entries.meaning: An instrument consisting of a number of perforated gauges fastened together at one end by a rivet, used for measuring the size of pearls

verbs.description: size (third-person singular simple present sizes, present participle sizing, simple past and past participle sized)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To adjust the size of; to make a certain size.
examples: a statute  […]  to size weights, and measures

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To classify or arrange by size.

entries.meaning: (military) To take the height of men, in order to place them in the ranks according to their stature.
(mining) To sift (pieces of ore or metal) in order to separate the finer from the coarser parts.
(transitive, colloquial) To approximate the dimensions, estimate the size of.
(intransitive) To take a greater size; to increase in size.
examples: Our desires give them fashion, and so, / As they wax lesser, fall, as they size, grow.

entries.meaning: (UK, Cambridge University, obsolete) To order food or drink from the buttery; hence, to enter a score, as upon the buttery book.
(transitive, obsolete) To swell; to increase the bulk of.

description: From Middle English syse, of unclear origin; related to Old Italian sisa (“a glue used by painters”), perhaps ultimately related to size / syse (“amount”), or perhaps shortened from assisa, from assiso (“to make to sit, to seat, to place”)

entries.meaning: A thin, weak glue used as primer for paper or canvas intended to be painted upon.
Wallpaper paste.
The thickened crust on coagulated blood.
Any viscous substance, such as gilder's varnish.

verbs.description: size (third-person singular simple present sizes, present participle sizing, simple past and past participle sized)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To apply glue or other primer to a surface which is to be painted.
Alternative form of sice (“number six in dice games”)
